Authors:
Chanintorn Doungsa-ard, Alistair Ross McTaggart, Roger G.
Shivas, Andrew D.W. Geering
Title: Phylogeny and taxonomy of the genus Uromycladium
Journal: Persoonia: Molecular Phylogeny and Evolution of Fungi
Abstract:
Uromycladium (Pucciniales) is a genus of rust fungi that
infects three closely related plant genera, Acacia, Falcataria and
Paraserianthes, in the Fabaceae. At the commencement of this study,
Uromycladium contained ten known species, namely U. acaciae (syn. U.
bisporum), U. alpinum, U. falcatarium, U. fusisporum, U. maritimum, U.
naracoortensis, U. robinsonii, U. simplex, U. notabile and U.
tepperianum. One of these species, Uromycladium tepperianum, has long
been considered to represent a complex of gall forming species that were
widespread in Australia, infecting over a hundred species of Acacia
(Chapter 1). By using morphological, biological and molecular
phylogenetic characteristics, U. tepperianum was divided into sixteen
provisional species that were mostly host-specific (Chapters 2 and 3).
Another gall forming rust, U. notabile, was found to occur on six
species of Acacia based on a similar systematic approach (Chapter 4).
Consequently, a new provisional species, Uromycladium sp. O, was
proposed for the gall rust on A. trudgeniana in Western Australia. This
Chapter investigates the phylogenetic relationships between 83 specimens
of Uromycladium with a combined dataset of the sequences of the Small
Subunit, Internal transcribed Spacer and Large Subunit regions of
nuclear ribosomal DNA, and the mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase subunit
3 of mitochondrial DNA. The genus Uromycladium was shown to be
monophyletic and five provisional species of Uromycladium are described
based on host, morphology and phylogenetic concordance.
